text:
Broadway, west side, north from and including 45th Street.  At the extreme left is a part of the new Hotel Astor. The Astor and Gaiety theaters are shown.

April, 1909

Wurts Brothers.

[handwritten] Slide #149
NEG # 3184 [/handwritten]

Broadway, west side, from, but not including 47th Street, to and including 45th Street. Churchill's Restaurant, owned by a former police lieutenant, is shown at the right. Below it are the Gaiety and Astor theatres, and the Hotel Astor.
April, 1909.

Wurts Brothers.

1532-6 Broadway, at the N.E. corner of West 45th Street, showing the buildings that subsequently were replaced by Lowe's State Theatre. At the right margin appears a portion of the old New York Theatre.

October 31, 1915

Borough President of Manhattan
No. 943

1538-42 Broadway, adjoining and north of the N.E. corner of West 45th Street.

October 31, 1915

Borough President of Manhattan
No. 942

316 East 45th Street, (Before reconstruction)/
April 20, 1921.

The Astor Theatre, Broadway at the N.W. corner of 45th Street. January 29, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway, west side, from 45th to 46th Streets.
January 29, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway, west side, north from but not including 45th Street. This view also shows Seventh Ave, at the right, north from but not including 45th Street. About 1930.

Ewing Galloway.

Broadway, west side, north from and including 45th Street. February 22, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway, west side, north from and including 45th Street. February 22, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

West 45th Street, north side, west from (No. 149-157) a point east of Broadway and across same, showing prominently the Lyceum Theatre at No. 149-157; a structure adjoining the rear of Loew's State Theatre which has an entrance on Broadway, through the large office building at the N.E. corner. The edifice partially shown on the left is the Hotel Astor. Westward on 45th Street and between Broadway and Eighth Ave. is the Hotel Piccadilly. This set consists of a negative and a positive view.

September 1935.

W.P.A. Photo.

West 45th Street, north side, west from (No. 149-157) a point east of Broadway and across same, showing prominently the Lyceum Theatre at No. 149-157; a structure adjoining the rear of Loew's State Theatre which has an entrance on Broadway, through the large office building at the N.E. corner. The edifice partially shown on the left is the Hotel Astor. Westward on 45th Street and between Broadway and Eighth Ave. is the Hotel Piccadilly. This set consists of a negative and a positive view.

September 1935.

W.P.A. Photo.

Bijou and Morosco Theatres, 211-225 West 45th Street, north side, west
of Broadway.
July 13, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
(2 and 3)
A set of two views consisting of a negative and a positive, showing a
similar view.
September 1935.
W.P.A. Photo.
(4 and 5)
Another negative and a positive set showing only the Morosce Theatre (No. 217 West) and a further view westward. The large structure shown in this view,that was built upon the vacant lot seen in No. 1, is the
Hotel Piccadilly.
September 1935.
W.P.A. Photo.

Bijou and Morosco Theatres, 211-225 West 45th Street, north side, west
of Broadway.

West 45th Street, west from a point midway between Broadway and Eighth Ave., and across the latter, showing several of the theatres that line both sides of this street. Shown on the south side is the Booth, the Plymouth and the Golden Theatres. Facing same on the opposite side are the Music Box, Imperial and the C.B.S. (formerly the Avon) Theatres. This set, consisting of three positive and three negative views, shows several different portions of this Times Square theatre district.

November 29, 1935.

W.P.A. Photo.

View 1

View 3

Broadway, west side, at West 45th Street and southward, showing prominently the Astor Theatre (No. 1531-1537 Broadway) at the N.W. corner of same. Occupying the block front southward is the Hotel Astor. The triangular edifice appearing on the left is the Times Building. This area is popularly known as Times Square, though the buildings, on both sides bear Broadway addresses. These two views, consisting of a negative and a positive, comprise a set.

September 1935.

W.P.A. Photo.

West 45th Street, north side, west from a point midway between Broadway and Eighth Ave. and to the latter, showing three theatres; the Music Box (No. 239); the Imperial (No. 249) and the C.B.S. (No. 251). This set consists of a negative and a positive.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

West 45th Street, north side, west from a point midway between Broadway and Eighth Ave. and to the latter, showing three theatres; the Music Box (No. 239); the Imperial (No. 249) and the C.B.S. (No. 251). This set consists of a negative and a positive.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

Broadway, west side, from West 45th to 46th Streets, showing prominently the Astor at the N. W. corner. This former legitimate theatre is now used former York premiers of motion pictures. Playing at this date is "Lloyds of London." Above same is the Globe Theatre with a Minsky burlesque attraction. Subsequently the latter activities were curtailed by the enforcement of the edict of the Commissioner of License, eliminating the use of the word "burlesque" and the discontinuance of "Strip Tease" Acts.
1937
Views 1,2
W. P. A.
Federal Writers Project
N. Y. C. Guide

Broadway, west side, from West 45th to 46th Streets, showing prominently the Astor at the N. W. corner. This former legitimate theatre is now used former York premiers of motion pictures. Playing at this date is "Lloyds of London." Above same is the Globe Theatre with a Minsky burlesque attraction. Subsequently the latter activities were curtailed by the enforcement of the edict of the Commissioner of License, eliminating the use of the word "burlesque" and the discontinuance of "Strip Tease" Acts.
1937
Views 1,2
W. P. A.
Federal Writers Project
N. Y. C. Guide

Times Square, north from West 45th Street, showing the theatrical district of New York. The buildings on both sides of this open area bear Broadway numbers; while north of 47th Street (center, apex), Seventh Ave. regains its identity. This is a set of 2 views, No. 2 of which is from the Seventh Ave. side.

September 14, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Times Square, north from West 45th Street, showing the theatrical district of New York. The buildings on both sides of this open area bear Broadway numbers; while north of 47th Street (center, apex), Seventh Ave. regains its identity. This is a set of 2 views, No. 2 of which is from the Seventh Ave. side.

September 14, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
